196.
Natures Explication,
Eusorbium must do what Cochipils
will not: Opium must do what Lettice
posset will not; but first it must
be mixed up into a ridiculous Laudanum;
Colocyntida & Scammony must
effect what Manna, Sene & Rhubarb
will not: O brave Doctors! O capita
Helleboro digna! yet you are
the men that cry out against
poysons.
As though Scammony, Colocyntida,
Elaterium, Esula, Euphorbium, Ialapium,
Bryony, Asarum, Aaron, Hellebore,
and such like, as Cambogia, &c.
were not absolute Poysons. O but
they are tempered by the Art of the
skilful Doctor. Good words cost
no money, I wish it prove so. But I
pray Mr. Doctor if it be so, what
means the bleating of the sheep? I
mean, what is the reason your Medicaments
retain their vomiting quality
with convulsions of the stomach
which have Hellebore mixed, and
their purging quality with gripings
and
and Helmont's Vindication.
137
and such symptomes that have Scammony
mixed: thus you use to correct
poysons, thus you intend to cure
diseases. Minervam crassissimam!
But as a Jugler when his seats are
discovered, so you by this means become
ridiculous: you know the serious
check the Frog in Aesop received;
who as you do, would pretend
to be a Doctor, Cur tibi ipsi labra
livida non curas?
Coughs, Colds, Murres, Hoarsenesses,
Head-aches, Tooth-aches and
the like; nay oft-times the simple
Itch and Scab, doth reproach you
at home, and outdare you abroad,
and what is your excuse? they are
trivial cases.
By which it appears, that if other
diseases should become as common
as these, they would all be too mean
for the Doctors reverence; and good
reason, because they are above his
abilities.
